slide.text: "We just wrote a piece of code which is made out of two Java commands that change the text appearing on a button."
"However, we want to change the text on the button only after the user clicks it."
"To do so, we first give the piece of code we wrote a name. A piece of code with a name is called a function."
"How do we name a piece of code? We wrap it with curly brackets and preceed it with this line of code:"
"The grey parts are static and the colorful part is the name we give the function."
"We can now define that clicking the button should call the function and run the commands inside it."

"How do we define what functions should run when our button is clicked? Just like background color or font, onClick is also a property of the button View. It is a special property that allows us to choose which function will be called when the button is clicked."

exercise.question: "What function will be executed when the button is clicked?"

task.text: "In the Code screen, copy the two commands we wrote below the ’}’ sign. Wrap them with a function and give it a name. In the Design Screen, define the button’s onClick property to be the function you created."
